information:
According to Taiwo Oyedele, the Chairman of the Presidential Committee on Fiscal Policy and Tax Reforms, the proposed Tax Reform Bill includes a provision to exempt real estate transactions from Value Added Tax (VAT). Official statements indicate the bill also contains exemptions on stamp duties for rents below N10 million per month and capital gains tax on the sale of dwelling houses. The stated purpose of these reforms is to reduce the tax burden on the construction and real estate sectors, thereby lowering housing costs and improving affordability for low-income earners.

As of late April 2025, reports indicated that the Tax Reform Bill had been passed by the Nigerian House of Representatives and was awaiting approval from the Senate before requiring presidential assent. Taiwo Oyedele, Chairman of the Presidential Tax Reform Committee, had stated in January 2025 that the bills were expected to be passed into law in the first quarter of 2025, with implementation scheduled to begin on July 1, 2025. The Q1 2025 deadline for passage has been missed.

The proposed VAT exemption has received public support from Ahmed Dangiwa, the Minister of Housing and Urban Development, as well as from industry groups like the Council of Registered Builders of Nigeria (CORBON) and the Housing Development Advocacy Network (HDAN). However, the broader tax reform package faces opposition from labor unions. The President of the Trade Union Congress (TUC), Festus Osifo, described the bills as 'anti-worker,' with union objections focusing on provisions such as the minimum taxable income and the proposed scrapping of the Tertiary Education Trust Fund (TETFUND).

forecast.status_quo_outcome: No — as of today the exemption is not yet law; without Senate concurrence, any needed harmonization, and presidential assent before July 1, the question resolves No.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The Senate does not finalize the Tax Reform Bill in time (e.g., committee work, amendments, or scheduling delays around the June Sallah period push a vote into July). Alternatively, the Senate amends the bill, requiring harmonization that slips past July 1, or the President signs after July 1. A regulatory circular from FIRS alone (without an Act) would not count.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: The Senate passes the bill in May or early June with the VAT exemption intact; if amended, both chambers quickly harmonize and transmit to the President. The President, who has signaled support for the reforms, assents in June, enacting the VAT exemption for real estate before July 1.
forecast.rationale:
What I know: • The House of Representatives reportedly passed the Tax Reform Bill in late April 2025. • The bill includes an explicit VAT exemption for real estate transactions, alongside other sector-friendly measures (e.g., reliefs on stamp duties for low-to-mid rents and CGT for dwelling houses). • The package has executive backing (Presidential Committee on Fiscal Policy and Tax Reforms; supportive statements from the Housing Minister) and industry support. • Labor unions oppose parts of the broader package, and the earlier target of Q1 passage was missed. • Implementation was publicly targeted for July 1, 2025, implying the executive wants enactment before that date.

Process considerations: Nigeria’s legislative path still requires Senate passage, potential harmonization if texts differ, and presidential assent. While the President has up to 30 days to sign, he can sign immediately upon transmission for priority bills. The National Assembly can move quickly on fiscal legislation when prioritized (e.g., annual Finance Acts), but timing risks remain: committee stages, potential controversy in the omnibus bill, and likely breaks around Eid al-Adha in early June.

How I weigh it: • Status quo inertia favors No because the law is not yet enacted and legislative slippage is common. • However, key milestones are already met (House passage), executive support is clear, and the desired implementation date creates political pressure to finish by end-June. • The VAT exemption itself is unlikely to be the sticking point; the main risk is the broader package slowing the bill or forcing amendments/harmonization that push enactment into July.

Why not higher: The Q1 deadline was missed, indicating process friction. Senate timing, potential committee revisions, and the possibility of last-minute disputes or a late presidential signature could slip enactment past July 1. Legislative recesses and the Eid break compress the calendar.

Why not lower: Executive priority, House passage already in hand, and public signaling of a July 1 implementation date suggest real effort to meet the timeline. The President is likely to assent quickly once the bill arrives, and the real estate VAT exemption is politically palatable and aligned with affordability goals.

What would move my forecast up: • Senate fast-tracks the bill to second/third readings in May. • Public statements from Senate leadership committing to passage before June 15. • Committee reports showing minimal or no changes to the House’s VAT exemption text. • News of harmonization completed or an adopted “concurrent passage” without changes. • Confirmation that the bill has been transmitted to the President.

What would move my forecast down: • Senate referrals to multiple committees or indications of splitting the package. • Escalating labor opposition prompting reconsideration or broad amendments. • Signals of pushing implementation to a date after July 1. • Reports of scheduling delays or extended recess around Eid or into late June.
